candidates.name: Why StackBlitz Over CodeSandbox/Replit?
candidates.acceptedAnswer:
StackBlitz runs Node.js natively in the browser using WebContainers
                    Faster startup time (no container spin-up)
                    Native npm install support
                    Clean GitHub integration
                    Free for open-source projects

candidates.name: Why Separate Repository for Demo?
candidates.acceptedAnswer:
StackBlitz fetches entire repos - we wanted minimal demo, not full framework source
                    Independent versioning and updates
                    Cleaner demo experience without framework internals
                    Can mark as GitHub template for easy forking

candidates.name: Why Commit Hash in URL?
candidates.acceptedAnswer:
Immutable reference - specific version always works
                    Bypasses StackBlitz cache
                    Prevents breaking changes from affecting live demo
                    Can update main branch while keeping stable demo

candidates.name: Simplicity wins.
candidates.acceptedAnswer: Remove complexity ruthlessly. A direct onclick handler beat complex modal systems.

candidates.name: Git submodules are tricky.
candidates.acceptedAnswer: Either configure them properly or avoid them. Silent failures are the worst.

candidates.name: Cache is both friend and foe.
candidates.acceptedAnswer: Use commit hashes for immutable references and cache-busting.

candidates.name: ESM is the future.
candidates.acceptedAnswer: Modern JavaScript should use import, not require().

candidates.name: Real packages matter.
candidates.acceptedAnswer: Mock code doesn't showcase the actual developer experience.

candidates.name: Test production.
candidates.acceptedAnswer: Local development can hide deployment issues.
